Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Evolution Across the Biology Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project is the example it will produce of how to help students understand the nature of scientific investigation and the basic concepts of evolution. It will also help a dedicated group of faculty develop effective approaches for actively engaging students in their own education. The project will engage students in use of a diverse set of methods of inquiry in evolutionary biology to study the bases for change in hammerhead sharks in terms of evolution, structure/function, and information flow. The approach will be embedded across all four academic years of study from an introductory biology course to a senior year capstone course. The project will improve students' acquisition of important concepts across important sub-disciplines in evolutionary biology. Students completing multiple courses in the sequence will have cutting-edge experience with evolutionary concepts. Students completing two or more elective courses in the sequence will be eligible for a semester-long capstone research project.

The goals and scope of the project are to improve the teaching of evolution across the biology curriculum at this institution, to engage a majority of the faculty in doing so and to disseminate the effects of doing so to the general biology community. Activities geared to engaging students in studies of fitness and phenotypic performance focusing on development and refinement of hammerhead shark cephalofoils will serve as the initial core of the project and will be expanded as the project proceeds to include studies of other organisms. These activities will be introduced first at the introductory level (the second semester of introductory biology) and then will be threaded throughout lower-level biology courses and upper level electives. New techniques being used to enable these studies include use of a 3-D printer to produce shark models, computer simulations, and genetic sequencing to cultivate a broad understanding of key evolutionary concepts. Many of the studies enabled by the newly acquired equipment are new to Armstrong State University. The specific project activities will: 1. emphasize and reinforce a continuous theme of structure and function through inquiry-based instruction of evolution, genotype, phenotype, and natural selection; 2. engage students in 3D scanning, 3D printing, computer simulations, genetic sequencing, molecular modeling, and bioinformatics; and 3. build a continuous thread of student involvement and instruction, starting with the required courses of Introductory Biology II and Genetics and continuing through upper-level electives including Evolution, Epigenetics, Bioinformatics, and Functional Morphology.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolution is a core concept in biology, yet many students have misconceptions, doubts, and outright philosophical aversions about it. Literature suggests that both historical and contemporary college-level teaching methods of evolutionary concepts are often ineffective and students show little or no gain in comprehension even after taking dedicated lecture-based courses on the topic. We developed a novel vertical thread of engaged student learning dedicated to teaching evolution embedded across four academic years beginning with introductory biology and culminating in a capstone research experience. Our instructional methods move beyond traditional lecture settings and integrate studio-style activities and laboratory methods by linking required courses (Principles of Biology II and Genetics) with a variety of electives (Evolution, Functional Morphology, Epigenetics, and Bioinformatics) and an optional independent research project (Capstone in Advanced Research in Evolution). Evidence indicates the best way for students to deconstruct their misconceptions and lack of comprehension about evolution is to repeatedly expose them to the subject matter and have them directly test hypotheses through hands-on manipulation.

Our curriculum is designed to give students inquiry-based, hands-on experience testing the central tenets of evolution including structure, function, information flow, exchange, and storage. Students participating in this curriculum receive cutting-edge experience in the emerging fields of 3D scanning and printing, biomechanics, computer simulations and modeling, next-generation genomics, and bioinformatics. Activities common to all connected courses currently focus on the evolution of hammerhead sharks, which is designed to promote student excitement and curiosity. Furthermore, by connecting different courses, methods, and approaches to analyze hammerhead form, function, performance, and evolution, students develop critical thinking skills, increase knowledge retention, and move beyond the discrete, semester block mentality. Our curriculum is designed to be expanded and refreshed in the future with different model organisms, taking advantage of diverse faculty expertise.

In addition to improving student performance and comprehension, the use of emerging and in-demand technologies increases workplace and post-graduate education preparation. Moreover, our curriculum provides equity and access to technologies for underserved groups.  As of fall 2016, our student enrollment was approximately one-third underrepresented minorities and two-thirds female. The combination of skills development using the technologies and capstone research experiences provides opportunities and access for students that would not have been otherwise available prior to this project.

Over the two-year implementation process, our curriculum reached 2068 students, spanning eight separate course titles. Initially, our curriculum was restricted to biology majors (seven courses, 1840 students), but based on the success of the laboratory exercise in Principles of Biology II during the first year, we adapted that module for our non-majors biology course Concepts in Biology, reaching 228 students during the second year.

Performance data and grade distributions from the first two years of implementation suggest that students entering the vertical thread of courses showed minimal command and lack synthesis of the concepts, but students enrolled in the upper-level electives began to demonstrate comprehension. Since our curriculum changes are new, it is not possible to determine the overall progress of students matriculating through the entire program.  However, comparing upper-level electives before and after revisions showed an overall improvement in student performance and comprehension. Additionally, DFW rates (grades of D, F, or W) were reduced in upper-level electives following curriculum revisions.

Independent assessment of student attitudes and perceptions of learning gains provides more evidence of the positive impacts of our curriculum. As expected, as indicated in the literature, students with deep-seated beliefs in creationism were often unable to change these opinions with an increase in exposure to evolutionary concepts; however, there was evidence that some of these students showed growth in understanding and compartmentalization. Additionally, students overwhelmingly responded that the use of hands-on simulations and models had a positive impact on their learning, helped them visualize difficult concepts, and was an effective and enjoyable use of class time. Furthermore, students stated the curriculum helped them to better understand evolutionary concepts, improved their attitudes toward studying evolution, and helped dispel some misconceptions.

As our curriculum matures and more students progress through the complete vertical thread, we expect student performance to further improve.
